metadata.synopsis: The real Gale has died and now magical manifestation of himself appears to deliver a message: he has put in place an elaborate protocol that will turn a blank letter he has in his possession into a Scroll of True Resurrection, which the player can use to bring him back to life. In this scene he describes the protocol and urges the player to repeat the instructions back to him. The manifestation speaks with the voice and personality of Gale, but this is a pre-recorded message (even though the player can interact with the manifestation), which is why the language in the message itself is also more elaborate on purpose. Gale does not shy away from the theatrical from time to time.

16.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
16.text: Well met! I am a magical projection of Gale of Waterdeep, and if you see this manifestation, that means I have prematurely perished.
16.context: CinematicNodeContext: The speaker here is not the real Gale: Gale is dead. This is a magical projection of him (like the mirror image) or potentially a projection of his face alone floating in a magic haze.

59.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
59.text: However, for reasons that cannot be disclosed, it is of vital importance that my death be remedied at your earliest convenience.

27.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
27.text: You may rest assured that I do not speak out of self preservation alone: many lives depend on my return to the living within the span of two days.

41.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
41.text: I trust I have made myself clear?

29.speaker: Player
29.text: My god does not yet grant me the ability to perform such a deed.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: How am I supposed to bring you back to life?

25.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
25.text: I have upon my deceased person a magical item that can accomplish my return, but such is the value and rarity that it is protected by a multi-layered security protocol.

32.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
32.text: I will now explain the protocol:

14.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
14.text: Step one is to retrieve from my person a pouch I wear over my heart.

4.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
4.text: Next you must unthread the purple seam that seals it in a counter-clockwise fashion. Do not touch any other coloured strand.

73.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
73.text: Inside the pouch, you will find a folded letter and a tiny flute. Unfold the letter, and note the markings in the top and bottom corners. These are the notes you will need to play.

7.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
7.text: Starting from the bottom right, play the notes in correct order - clockwise this time.

17.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
17.text: Upon completion of the tune, a magma mephit will appear, which will pose the following question: I'ss k'cha t'chiss n'aga?

54.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
54.text: This is Ignan for 'What is my name?' The answer is 'K'ha'ssji'trach'ash'.
54.context: NodeContext: Kahs-she-trachh-awsh! The chhh is with the back of the throat.

90.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
90.text: Pronounce the name correctly and the mephit will breathe on the letter. Stay clear because the little scamp can melt metal.

76.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
76.text: Words will now appear on the letter's surface, effectively turning the letter into a Scroll of True Resurrection. Use it to bring me back to life.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: That's a very interesting protocol. I'm impressed.

74.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
74.text: Thank you. Now repeat my instructions back to me, please.

93.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
93.text: Humour me. I need to be absolutely certain you understand.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Fine, I'll play along. Step one: retrieve the pouch.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: I should unthread the scarlet seam in a counter-clockwise fashion.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: I should unthread the yellow seam in a counter-clockwise fashion.

82.speaker: Lae'zel
82.text: Chk - how quick your mind turns to mush. You unthread the purple seam.

26.speaker: Shadowheart
26.context: NodeContext: Annoyance, Player's getting some instructions wrong.

52.speaker: Astarion
52.text: Purple, darling. It's the purple seam.

85.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
85.text: The purple seam indeed. You then have access to the letter and the flute. Continue.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: I should play the notes starting at the bottom right corner.

61.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
61.text: Remember to play them clockwise! And after that?

37.speaker: Player
37.text: When a mephit appears I should say its name: K'ha'trach'ash'ssji.

19.speaker: Lae'zel
19.text: Bah - is it really so difficult? K'ha'ssji'trach'ash!

64.speaker: Shadowheart
64.text: Come on, you're just guessing now. It's K'ha'ssji'trach'ash.
64.context: NodeContext: Kahs-she-trawkk-awsh! Annoyance, Player's getting some instructions wrong.

72.speaker: Karlach
72.text: Wait! No! I know this one. K'ha's - sji - 'trach - 'ash!
72.context: NodeContext: Kahs-she-trawkk-awsh! She's delighted she knows the answer for once

8.speaker: Astarion
8.text: K'ha'ssji'trach'ash. The blighter is called K'ha'ssji'trach'ash.

9.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
9.text: Listen to your friend. It's K'ha'ssji'trach'ash.
9.context: NodeContext: Kahs-she-trachh-awsh! The chhh is with the back of the throat.

18.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
18.text: And pay attention to the 'trach' part. Chhh. Back of the throat.

77.speaker: Wyll
77.text: Hmm - I think it's the one ending in 'ash'. Easy mistake.

63.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
63.text: That's not even close. It's K'ha'ssji'trach'ash!

68.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
68.text: And pay attention to the 'trach' part. Chhh. Back of the throat.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: When a mephit appears I should say its name: K'ha'ash'ssji'trach.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: When a mephit appears I should say its name: K'ha'ssji'trach'ash.

1.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
1.text: Correct! But pay attention to the 'trach' part. Chhh. Back of the throat.

57.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
57.text: And so we have gone through the necessary steps again. It is gratifying to see your memory does not fail you!

0.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
0.text: Best of luck with the protocol! May my cold, dead hands soon be refilled with the warmth of life so they can shake yours in gratitude.
0.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale's magical projection disappears with a flash.

88.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
88.text: And so we have gone through the necessary steps again. Let's hope practice makes perfect in the end...

10.speaker: Player
10.text: I should play the notes starting at the top right corner.

42.speaker: Lae'zel
42.text: Focus, k'chakhi. You play starting at the bottom right.

81.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
81.text: Quite right. You start at the bottom right corner - and remember to play them clockwise! After that?

69.speaker: Shadowheart
69.text: Did you listen at all? Bottom right.
69.context: NodeContext: Annoyance, Player's getting some instructions wrong.

87.speaker: Wyll
87.text: No, no - unless my mind's gone a-muddle, I think you mean 'bottom right'.

44.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
44.text: No, no, no. You start at the bottom right corner - and remember to play them clockwise! After that?

80.speaker: Player
80.text: I should play the notes starting at the bottom left corner.

39.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
39.text: Almost: it's the purple seam. You then have access to the letter and the flute. Continue.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: I should unthread the purple seam in a counter-clockwise fashion.

51.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
51.text: Right. You then have access to the letter and the flute. Go on.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: Forget it. I'm going to resurrect you now if that's all right with you.

28.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
28.text: Have it your way. I can only hope your memory stretches further than your patience.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: Unsummon yourself, Gale. Before I find a way to kill you twice.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: I got it. Seams, notes, names - the lot.

94.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
94.text: In that case, this will be an easy exercise. Step one?

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Are you kidding me? Absolutely not.

24.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
24.text: I'm not trying to try your patience, I simply need to be absolutely certain you understand.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Fine, I promise I will do so.

45.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
45.text: Excellent. Now repeat my instructions back to me, please.

5.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
5.text: I think ingenious is the word you're looking for. Now repeat my instructions back to me, please.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: A Scroll of True Resurrection? Sounds valuable...

2.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
2.text: So it is: our lives depend on it. Now repeat my instructions back to me, please.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: I'm afraid your pouch is as done for as you are. It's been destroyed.

86.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
86.text: Then, my overly incautious friend, I urge you to find some other means of restoring my vitality. Our very lives depend on it.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: Why do many lives depend on your return to the living?

36.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
36.text: That would be covered by the 'for reasons that cannot be disclosed' clause, so let's move on.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: I'm starting to think you're better off dead.

56.speaker: GROUP_ORI_SoundsLikeGale
56.text: A grave error in judgement indeed, which we'll pretend was never spoken.
